column5: Include a variety of fresh foods in your diet to ensure a balanced intake of essential nutrients.
column6: If at risk, consider vitamin C supplements under the guidance of a healthcare professional.
column7: Be mindful of cooking methods, as boiling and overcooking can deplete the vitamin C content in foods.

column2: Sepsis is a life-threatening condition triggered by the body's extreme response to infection, leading to widespread inflammation and organ dysfunction. It can result from various infections, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, or abdominal infections. Prompt medical intervention is crucial to prevent complications and improve outcomes.
column3: Recognize and seek medical attention promptly for signs of infection, such as fever, rapid heartbeat, and altered mental state.
column4: Practice good hygiene to prevent infections that can lead to sepsis, including proper handwashing and wound care.
column5: Stay up-to-date on vaccinations to reduce the risk of infections that can potentially lead to sepsis.
column6: Take prescribed antibiotics as directed by healthcare professionals to effectively treat bacterial infections and prevent their progression to sepsis.
column7: Schedule regular health check-ups to monitor and manage underlying health conditions that may increase susceptibility to infections and sepsis.

column2: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) are infections that are typically transmitted through sexual contact. Common examples include chlamydia, gonorrhea, syphilis, and human papillomavirus (HPV). STIs can be asymptomatic or cause a range of symptoms, and some may lead to serious health complications if left untreated.
column3: Consistent condom use during sexual activity can significantly reduce the risk of STI transmission.
column4: Regular STI testing and communication with sexual partners about testing and sexual health are crucial.
column5: Limiting the number of sexual partners and choosing partners who have been tested for STIs can help lower the risk.
column6: Getting vaccinated against certain STIs, such as HPV, can provide additional protection.
column7: Practicing good personal hygiene and seeking prompt medical attention if any symptoms or concerns arise.

column2: Shaken Baby Syndrome (SBS) is a severe form of child abuse caused by violently shaking an infant or young child, leading to brain injury. Symptoms include lethargy, difficulty breathing, and neurological problems.
column3: Always support an infant's head and neck when lifting or carrying.
column4: Ensure caregivers are aware of the dangers of shaking and educate them on alternative soothing methods.
column5: If feeling overwhelmed or stressed, seek support from family, friends, or professionals.
column6: Schedule regular checkups for infants to monitor their development and address any concerns promptly.
column7: Never shake a baby, even in frustration or anger; instead, find calm and safe ways to manage stress.

column2: Shigellosis is an infectious disease caused by the Shigella bacteria, primarily transmitted through contaminated food or water. Symptoms include diarrhea, abdominal cramps, fever, and nausea. The bacteria can spread easily in crowded or unsanitary conditions.
column3: Practice thorough handwashing with soap and water, especially after using the toilet or changing diapers.
column4: Avoid consuming contaminated food or water, and ensure that food is properly cooked and stored.
column5: Maintain personal hygiene to prevent the spread of the bacteria, including regular bathing and washing of hands.
column6: Be cautious in crowded or communal settings, as the bacteria can spread easily in such environments.
column7: Seek medical attention promptly if symptoms arise, and follow prescribed antibiotic treatment as recommended by healthcare professionals.

column2: Shin splints, or medial tibial stress syndrome, is a common lower leg injury characterized by pain along the shinbone (tibia) due to inflammation of the muscles, tendons, and bone tissue. It often occurs in athletes engaged in activities involving repetitive stress on the legs, such as running or high-impact sports.
column3: Ensure you wear appropriate footwear with good arch support to minimize impact on the shins.
column4: Avoid sudden increases in exercise intensity; gradually build up the intensity and duration of your workouts.
column5: Incorporate low-impact activities like swimming or cycling to reduce strain on the shins.
column6: Include calf stretches and exercises that strengthen the shin muscles to improve overall leg stability.
column7: Allow sufficient time for rest and recovery between intense workouts to prevent overuse and reduce the risk of shin splints.

column2: Shingles, also known as herpes zoster, is a viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus—the same virus that causes chickenpox. After a person has had chickenpox, the virus can reactivate, leading to the development of painful rashes and blisters along a specific nerve pathway.
column3: Seek vaccination, as the shingles vaccine can reduce the risk and severity of the condition.
column4: Practice good hygiene to avoid spreading the virus; keep the rash covered and wash hands frequently.
column5: Avoid close contact with individuals at higher risk, such as pregnant women and people with weakened immune systems.
column6: Manage stress, as it can contribute to the reactivation of the virus.
column7: Consult a healthcare professional promptly if symptoms of shingles, such as pain or a rash, develop.

column2: Sickle-cell anemia is a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal hemoglobin, causing red blood cells to assume a rigid, sickle shape. This can lead to blockages in blood vessels, causing pain, anemia, and organ damage. Individuals with sickle-cell anemia inherit two copies of the abnormal hemoglobin gene.
column3: Stay hydrated to prevent dehydration, which can trigger a sickle-cell crisis.
column4: Avoid extreme temperatures, as both cold and heat can exacerbate symptoms.
column5: Engage in regular medical check-ups to monitor and manage the condition.
column6: Take prescribed medications, such as hydroxyurea, to reduce the frequency of crises.
column7: Seek prompt medical attention for any signs of infection or worsening symptoms.

column2: Smallpox is a highly contagious viral disease caused by the variola virus. It is characterized by a distinctive rash with raised, fluid-filled blisters that can lead to severe illness and, in some cases, death. The World Health Organization (WHO) successfully eradicated smallpox through a global vaccination campaign, and it remains the only human disease eradicated to date.
column3: Vaccination: Ensure timely smallpox vaccination to build immunity.
column4: Isolation: Quarantine individuals with suspected or confirmed cases to prevent the spread of the virus.
column5: Strict hygiene: Practice thorough handwashing and maintain personal hygiene to minimize the risk of transmission.
column6: Surveillance: Monitor and report suspected cases promptly to facilitate early intervention.
column7: Travel restrictions: Implement travel restrictions in affected areas to contain the spread of the virus.

column2: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a rare but severe skin reaction that is often triggered by medications or infections. It manifests with flu-like symptoms, followed by a painful, blistering rash that can lead to the detachment of the top layer of skin.
column3: Identify and avoid medications or substances that have previously triggered SJS in the individual.
column4: Consult a healthcare professional before starting any new medication to ensure it does not pose a risk of triggering SJS.
column5: If an individual experiences any signs of SJS, such as skin rash or mucous membrane involvement, discontinue the suspected medication promptly and seek medical attention.
column6: Keep a close watch on any skin changes or symptoms, especially when introducing new medications, and report them to a healthcare provider promptly.
column7: Consider wearing a medical alert bracelet to inform emergency medical personnel about the individual's history of Stevens-Johnson syndrome in case of unforeseen medical emergencies.

column2: Stomach ulcers, also known as peptic ulcers, are open sores that develop on the inner lining of the stomach. They are often caused by the bacterium Helicobacter pylori or long-term use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Symptoms may include burning stomach pain, bloating, nausea, and heartburn.
column3: Refrain from prolonged use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs like aspirin and ibuprofen, as they can contribute to ulcer formation.
column4: Excessive alcohol consumption can irritate the stomach lining, so moderate or eliminate alcohol intake.
column5: Smoking can delay ulcer healing and increase the risk of complications; quitting is beneficial for overall stomach health.
column6: Consume a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains while avoiding spicy and acidic foods that may aggravate ulcers.
column7: Practice stress-reducing techniques such as meditation or yoga, as stress can exacerbate ulcer symptoms and delay healing.

column2: Strep throat is a bacterial infection caused by Group A Streptococcus bacteria, commonly resulting in a sore throat, fever, and difficulty swallowing. It is usually treated with antibiotics to prevent complications. Precautions include:
column3: Finish the prescribed antibiotic course even if symptoms improve to ensure the bacteria are fully eradicated.
column4: Avoid sharing utensils, towels, or toothbrushes to prevent the spread of the infection.
column5: Practice frequent handwashing to reduce the risk of transmitting the bacteria.
column6: Cover your mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing, and dispose of tissues properly to prevent the spread of the bacteria.
column7: Minimize contact with individuals who have strep throat until they have been on antibiotics for at least 24 hours to prevent transmission.

column2: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to the brain is disrupted, either by a blocked blood vessel (ischemic stroke) or bleeding in the brain (hemorrhagic stroke). It can result in severe damage to brain cells and various physical and cognitive impairments.
column3: Manage and monitor blood pressure regularly to reduce the risk of stroke.
column4: Adopt a balanced diet low in salt, saturated fats, and cholesterol to promote cardiovascular health.
column5: Engage in physical activity to maintain a healthy weight and improve overall cardiovascular fitness.
column6: Smoking increases stroke risk; quitting is a crucial step toward reducing this risk.
column7: Moderation in alcohol intake helps in preventing strokes and other cardiovascular issues.

column2: Subconjunctival hemorrhage is a condition where blood accumulates under the conjunctiva, the clear membrane covering the white part of the eye. It is typically harmless and often caused by minor trauma or a sudden increase in pressure, such as during a bout of coughing.
column3: Avoid rubbing your eyes, as this can worsen the condition.
column4: Steer clear of activities that may increase eye pressure, like heavy lifting or strenuous exercise.
column5: Refrain from using blood-thinning medications without consulting a healthcare professional.
column6: Protect your eyes from irritation, such as avoiding exposure to smoke or dusty environments.
column7: If the subconjunctival hemorrhage is recurrent or associated with other symptoms, seek prompt medical advice.

column2: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It progresses through multiple stages, including primary, secondary, latent, and tertiary. Early symptoms may include painless sores, rash, and flu-like symptoms, while untreated syphilis can lead to severe complications affecting the heart, brain, and other organs.
column3: Consistent condom use during sexual activity helps reduce the risk of syphilis transmission.
column4: Regular STI screenings, especially for individuals with multiple sexual partners or high-risk behaviors, can detect syphilis early.
column5: Avoiding direct contact with syphilis sores or rashes on an infected person can prevent transmission.
column6: Communication and honesty about sexual health with partners are crucial to prevent the spread of syphilis.
column7: Seeking prompt medical attention and completing the prescribed antibiotic treatment if diagnosed with syphilis helps prevent complications and further transmission.

column2: Taeniasis is a parasitic infection caused by tapeworms of the Taenia genus, such as Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) or Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm). These tapeworms primarily infect the human intestines through the consumption of undercooked or raw contaminated meat, leading to symptoms like abdominal discomfort and weight loss.
column3: Ensure thorough cooking of meat, especially pork and beef, to kill the larvae responsible for taeniasis.
column4: Practice good personal hygiene, including proper handwashing, to minimize the risk of ingesting contaminated food.
column5: Avoid consuming raw or undercooked meat, as it may contain viable tapeworm larvae.
column6: Properly treat and dispose of human and animal feces to prevent the contamination of water and food sources.
column7: Implement regular deworming programs for animals, particularly pigs and cattle, to reduce the transmission of tapeworms to humans.

column2: Taeniasis is an intestinal infection caused by tapeworms of the genus Taenia, while cysticercosis is a tissue infection caused by the larval stage of these tapeworms. The most common species involved is Taenia solium, which can lead to cysticercosis when its eggs are ingested and develop into larvae in tissues such as the muscles or brain.
column3: Practice thorough hand hygiene, especially after using the toilet and before handling food, to prevent oral ingestion of tapeworm eggs.
column4: Ensure proper cooking of pork and beef, as thorough cooking kills the tapeworm larvae, reducing the risk of infection.
column5: Avoid consuming raw or undercooked meat, particularly pork, as it may contain viable cysts.
column6: Maintain good sanitation and hygiene in living environments to prevent contamination with tapeworm eggs.
column7: Seek medical advice promptly if you suspect infection or experience symptoms such as abdominal pain, nausea, or neurological symptoms, as early diagnosis and treatment are crucial.

column2: Tay-Sachs disease is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the deficiency of an enzyme called hexosaminidase A, leading to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in the nerve cells. This accumulation causes progressive neurological deterioration, usually beginning in infancy, and sadly, there is no cure for this fatal condition.
column3: Individuals with a family history of Tay-Sachs should undergo genetic counseling to assess the risk of passing on the mutated gene.
column4: Couples with a higher risk should consider prenatal testing to identify the presence of the Tay-Sachs gene during pregnancy.
column5: It is advisable for individuals of Ashkenazi Jewish descent, as they have a higher carrier frequency, to undergo carrier screening before planning a family.
column6: Raising awareness about Tay-Sachs within at-risk communities can promote informed family planning and early detection.
column7: For affected individuals, providing appropriate medical and supportive care can enhance the quality of life and manage symptoms.

column2: Tennis elbow, or lateral epicondylitis, is a condition characterized by pain and inflammation on the outer part of the elbow. It is often caused by repetitive strain and overuse of the forearm and wrist, leading to damage of the tendons attached to the lateral epicondyle.
column3: Allow sufficient time for the affected arm to rest and recover.
column4: Ensure proper technique while engaging in activities that involve gripping or repetitive wrist movements.
column5: Consider using an elbow brace or strap to provide support and reduce strain.
column6: Apply ice to the affected area for short durations to alleviate pain and inflammation.
column7: Gradually reintroduce strengthening exercises under the guidance of a healthcare professional to avoid exacerbating the condition.

column2: Tetanus is a potentially fatal bacterial infection caused by Clostridium tetani, commonly found in soil, dust, and manure. The bacteria enter the body through wounds or cuts, producing a potent toxin that affects the nervous system. Symptoms include muscle stiffness, spasms, and difficulty swallowing, and the disease can be prevented through vaccination.
column3: Ensure up-to-date tetanus vaccinations to prevent the onset of the disease.
column4: Promptly clean and disinfect any wounds or cuts to minimize the risk of bacterial entry.
column5: Adults should receive tetanus booster shots every 10 years to maintain immunity.
column6: Consult a healthcare professional immediately if you experience an injury that could expose you to tetanus.
column7: Practicing good hygiene, such as washing hands regularly, can help reduce the risk of infection.

column2: Thalassaemia is a genetic blood disorder characterized by abnormal hemoglobin production, leading to a reduced ability of red blood cells to carry oxygen. There are two main types: alpha thalassemia and beta thalassemia.
column3: Regular blood transfusions are often necessary to maintain adequate hemoglobin levels.
column4: Iron chelation therapy helps prevent iron overload resulting from frequent transfusions.
column5: Genetic counseling is crucial for families with a history of thalassemia to understand and manage the risk of passing on the genetic mutation.
column6: Avoid excessive iron and vitamin C intake, as it can enhance iron absorption, contributing to iron overload.
column7: Infections should be promptly treated, as thalassemia patients may be more susceptible to complications.

column2: Tinnitus is a condition characterized by the perception of noise or ringing in the ears, often described as a persistent buzzing, hissing, or clicking sound. It can be caused by various factors, including exposure to loud noise, age-related hearing loss, earwax blockage, or underlying health conditions.
column3: Use ear protection, such as earplugs, in loud environments to prevent further damage to the auditory system.
column4: Avoid prolonged exposure to loud music or environments and take breaks to give your ears a rest.
column5: Schedule regular check-ups with an audiologist to monitor your hearing health and address any concerns promptly.
column6: Practice stress-reducing techniques like meditation or yoga, as stress can exacerbate tinnitus symptoms.
column7: Maintain good ear hygiene by avoiding the use of cotton swabs, which can push earwax deeper, and seek professional assistance if earwax buildup is a concern.

column2: Tonsillitis is the inflammation of the tonsils, which are two oval-shaped pads of tissue at the back of the throat. It is commonly caused by viral or bacterial infections, leading to symptoms such as sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and swollen lymph nodes.
column3: Stay hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids to soothe the throat and prevent dehydration.
column4: Get adequate rest to support the body's immune system in fighting the infection.
column5: Gargle with warm saltwater to alleviate throat discomfort and reduce inflammation.
column6: Avoid irritants like smoking and exposure to secondhand smoke, as they can exacerbate throat irritation.
column7: Take prescribed antibiotics if the tonsillitis is bacterial in origin, and follow the full course of medication as directed by a healthcare professional.

column2: Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition, often associated with bacterial infections, most commonly Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. It can affect men, women, and children and is often linked to tampon use, skin wounds, or surgical procedures.
column3: Change tampons regularly, at least every 4-8 hours, to minimize the risk of bacterial growth.
column4: Use the lowest absorbency tampon necessary for your menstrual flow to reduce the likelihood of TSS.
column5: Alternate between tampons and sanitary napkins during your menstrual period to allow for better airflow.
column6: Wash hands thoroughly before and after inserting tampons to prevent introducing bacteria.
column7: Be aware of the symptoms of TSS, such as sudden high fever, low blood pressure, vomiting, and a rash resembling sunburn, and seek medical attention promptly if they occur.

column2: Trachoma is a contagious eye infection caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. It primarily affects the conjunctiva and cornea, leading to progressive scarring that can result in visual impairment or blindness. It is a leading cause of preventable blindness in developing countries, particularly in areas with poor sanitation.
column3: Encourage regular face washing to reduce the spread of the infection.
column4: Ensure access to clean water for personal and domestic hygiene, as the bacteria can spread through contaminated water.
column5: Administer antibiotics as prescribed by healthcare professionals for affected individuals and communities to treat and prevent the spread.
column6: Implement measures to improve sanitation and reduce the prevalence of flies, which can transmit the infection.
column7: Educate communities about the importance of maintaining good hygiene practices to prevent the transmission of trachoma.

column2: Trichinosis, also known as trichinellosis, is a parasitic infection caused by the roundworm Trichinella spiralis. People can contract the disease by consuming undercooked or raw meat, particularly pork, that is infected with the parasite. Symptoms include muscle pain, fever, and gastrointestinal issues.
column3: Cook meat thoroughly: Ensure pork and other meats are cooked to a safe internal temperature of at least 160°F (71°C) to kill the parasite.
column4: Avoid raw or undercooked meats: Refrain from consuming raw or undercooked pork, wild game, and other potentially infected meats.
column5: Freeze meat: If wild game is to be consumed, freezing it at -15°C (5°F) or colder for several weeks can help kill the larvae.
column6: Practice good hygiene: Wash hands thoroughly with soap and water, especially after handling raw meat, to prevent the spread of the parasite.
column7: Educate yourself: Be aware of the risks associated with consuming raw or undercooked meats and take necessary precautions to minimize the chances of contracting trichinosis.

column2: Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. Common symptoms include itching, burning, and discharge in women, while men may experience irritation and discharge. It can be easily treated with antibiotics, but if left untreated, it can lead to complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease.
column3: Practice safe sex by using condoms consistently and correctly.
column4: Get regular screenings for sexually transmitted infections, especially if you have multiple sexual partners.
column5: Ensure your sexual partners are also tested and treated if necessary.
column6: Abstain from sexual activity if you or your partner is diagnosed with trichomoniasis.
column7: Maintain good personal hygiene, including regular genital area cleaning, to reduce the risk of infection.

column2: Tuberculosis (TB) is a bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, primarily affecting the lungs. It spreads through the air when an infected person coughs or sneezes. Symptoms include persistent cough, weight loss, and fatigue.
column3: Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or elbow when coughing or sneezing.
column4: Ensure proper ventilation in living spaces to reduce the concentration of airborne bacteria.
column5: Minimize close contact with individuals diagnosed with TB to prevent transmission.
column6: Seek medical attention promptly if experiencing TB symptoms or if exposed to someone with active TB.
column7: If prescribed antibiotics for TB, complete the full course of treatment as directed by a healthcare professional to prevent drug-resistant strains.

column2: Tularemia, also known as rabbit fever, is a bacterial infection caused by the bacterium Francisella tularensis. It primarily affects rabbits and other small mammals, but humans can contract the disease through contact with infected animals, contaminated water, or insect bites. Symptoms include fever, skin ulcers, and swollen lymph nodes.
column3: Steer clear of wild rodents, hares, and other animals that may carry the bacteria.
column4: Protect against insect bites by applying DEET-containing insect repellents to exposed skin.
column5: When in areas where tularemia may be present, wear gloves and other protective clothing to minimize direct skin contact.
column6: If handling or consuming game meat, ensure it is cooked thoroughly to kill any potential bacteria.
column7: Wash hands frequently, especially after outdoor activities, to reduce the risk of infection from contaminated surfaces or materials.

column2: Turner syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting females, characterized by the partial or complete absence of one X chromosome. Common features include short stature, webbed neck, and infertility.
column3: Regular medical check-ups to monitor growth and development.
column4: Hormone replacement therapy to address hormonal deficiencies.
column6: Bone density assessments to monitor skeletal health.
column7: Educational support to manage learning difficulties, if present.

column2: Urticaria, commonly known as hives, is a skin condition characterized by the sudden appearance of itchy, raised welts on the skin. These welts can vary in size and shape and often result from an allergic reaction, stress, or other triggers. The condition is usually temporary but can cause discomfort and may recur.
column3: Pinpoint and avoid specific allergens or triggers that may induce urticaria.
column4: Wear loose-fitting clothes to minimize friction and irritation on the skin.
column5: Adopt a balanced diet rich in nutrients to support overall skin health.
column6: Drink plenty of water to keep the skin hydrated, reducing the likelihood of flare-ups.
column7: Practice stress-reducing techniques, such as meditation or yoga, to minimize emotional triggers for urticaria.

column2: Varicose veins are enlarged, twisted veins that commonly occur in the legs due to weakened or damaged vein walls and valves, leading to poor blood circulation. They may cause pain, swelling, and aching, and are often visible beneath the skin's surface.
column3: Engage in activities that promote good blood circulation, such as walking or swimming.
column4: Elevate your legs whenever possible to reduce pressure on veins.
column5: Wear compression stockings to support blood flow and minimize swelling.
column6: Maintain a diet rich in fiber and low in salt to promote overall vascular health.
column7: Take breaks to move and avoid extended periods of sitting or standing to prevent blood pooling.

column2: Vasovagal syncope is a common form of fainting triggered by a sudden drop in heart rate and blood pressure, resulting in temporary loss of consciousness. It often occurs in response to stress, pain, or emotional triggers.
column3: Stay hydrated: Maintain adequate fluid intake to prevent dehydration, a common trigger.
column4: Avoid prolonged standing: Change positions slowly and take breaks to prevent blood pooling and fainting.
column5: Identify triggers: Recognize and manage situations that may provoke a vasovagal response.
column6: Gradual rising: When getting up from a lying or sitting position, do so slowly to minimize sudden drops in blood pressure.
column7: Counterpressure maneuvers: Cross legs and tense muscles to improve blood flow and prevent syncope during warning signs.

column2: Vitamin B12 deficiency occurs when the body lacks sufficient levels of this essential vitamin, crucial for red blood cell formation, neurological function, and DNA synthesis. Common causes include inadequate dietary intake, malabsorption issues, or certain medical conditions.
column3: Ensure a diet rich in B12 sources like meat, fish, dairy, and fortified foods.
column4: Consider B12 supplements if dietary intake is insufficient, under medical guidance.
column5: Monitor B12 levels through blood tests, especially for individuals at risk.
column6: Treat conditions affecting B12 absorption, such as pernicious anemia or gastrointestinal disorders.
column7: Avoid excessive alcohol consumption, which can hinder B12 absorption, and quit smoking if applicable.

column2: Vitiligo is a skin condition characterized by the loss of pigment-producing cells, resulting in white patches on the skin. It occurs when the immune system mistakenly attacks and destroys melanocytes, leading to depigmentation.
column3: Use sunscreen with a high SPF to protect depigmented areas from sunburn and prevent worsening of the condition.
column4: Use camouflage makeup to conceal white patches and improve cosmetic appearance.
column5: Choose mild soaps and detergents to prevent skin irritation, which can exacerbate vitiligo.
column6: Monitor skin changes and consult a dermatologist for regular check-ups to address any new developments or treatment options.
column7: Seek emotional support and counseling to cope with the psychological impact of vitiligo, as stress can potentially exacerbate the condition.

column2: Warkany syndrome, also known as DiGeorge syndrome 2, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by facial abnormalities, intellectual disabilities, and congenital heart defects. It is caused by mutations in the GATA4 gene.
column3: Early medical evaluation and genetic testing are crucial for accurate diagnosis and timely intervention.
column4: Regular monitoring of cardiac health and prompt intervention for any detected heart abnormalities.
column5: Comprehensive developmental assessments and early intervention programs to address intellectual disabilities.
column6: Collaborate with a multidisciplinary healthcare team, including geneticists, cardiologists, and developmental specialists.
column7: Provide emotional and social support for individuals and families coping with the challenges of Warkany syndrome.

column2: Warts are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), which infects the top layer of skin and causes rapid cell growthWarts are highly contagious and can spread through direct skin-to-skin contact or by touching surfaces contaminated with the virus.
column3: Refrain from touching warts on yourself or others to prevent the spread of the virus.
column4: Moist environments facilitate the transmission of HPV, so keeping hands dry can reduce the risk of contracting or spreading warts.
column5: Warts can appear around nails, and avoiding nail biting can minimize the risk of transferring the virus from hands to mouth.
column6: Wear flip-flops or sandals in communal showers or pool areas to reduce the risk of plantar wart transmission.
column7: Maintain good personal hygiene practices, including regular handwashing, to minimize the likelihood of HPV transmission.

column2: Yaws is a tropical infectious disease caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum subspecies pertenue. It primarily affects skin, bone, and cartilage, leading to chronic disfiguring lesions. Yaws is transmitted through direct skin-to-skin contact, often in communities with poor hygiene and limited access to healthcare.
column3: Practice good personal hygiene, including regular handwashing with soap and water.
column4: Avoid direct skin-to-skin contact with individuals showing yaws lesions or ulcers.
column5: Promote community awareness and education about yaws transmission and preventive measures.
column6: Encourage the use of protective clothing, such as long sleeves and pants, to reduce skin exposure.
column7: Ensure timely diagnosis and treatment of yaws cases with appropriate antibiotics, as early intervention can prevent further spread.

column2: Yellow fever is a viral hemorrhagic fever transmitted by mosquitoes, primarily in tropical regions of Africa and South America. Symptoms include fever, jaundice, and severe bleeding, with a high mortality rate.
column3: Ensure you are vaccinated against yellow fever before traveling to endemic areas.
column4: Use insect repellent, wear long sleeves, and use bed nets to minimize mosquito exposure.
column5: Avoid travel to high-risk areas during peak mosquito activity times.
column6: Eliminate standing water around living and sleeping areas to reduce mosquito breeding sites.
column7: Be aware of symptoms and seek medical attention promptly if you experience fever, especially after visiting endemic regions.

column2: Zika virus is a mosquito-borne viral infection primarily transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. It gained global attention due to the 2015-2016 outbreak, particularly in the Americas. While symptoms are usually mild, the virus is of concern in pregnant women as it can lead to birth defects like microcephaly.
column3: Use insect repellent containing DEET, picaridin, or other recommended ingredients.
column4: Wear long-sleeved shirts and long pants to minimize exposed skin.
column5: Stay in places with air conditioning or screens to reduce mosquito exposure.
column6: Pregnant women should avoid travel to areas with known Zika transmission.
column7: Practice safe sex or abstain from sexual activity with a partner who has traveled to Zika-affected areas, especially if pregnant or trying to conceive.

column2: Lactose intolerance is a digestive disorder where the body lacks the enzyme lactase needed to properly break down lactose, the sugar found in milk and dairy products. Common symptoms include bloating, gas, diarrhea, and abdominal discomfort after consuming lactose-containing foods. While not life-threatening, it can significantly impact dietary choices and nutrient intake.
column3: Opt for lactose-free milk and dairy products to enjoy the taste without digestive discomfort.
column4: Check product labels for hidden sources of lactose, such as whey or milk solids, in processed foods.
column5: Gradually introduce small amounts of lactose-containing foods to assess tolerance levels.
column6: Take over-the-counter lactase supplements before consuming dairy to aid in lactose digestion.
column7: Explore alternative sources of calcium and vitamin D from non-dairy sources like fortified plant-based milks, leafy greens, and supplements.

column2: papilloedema is a medical condition characterized by the swelling of the optic disc (the point where the optic nerve enters the eye) due to increased intracranial pressure. It is often a sign of an underlying condition affecting the brain.
column3: Regular eye examinations are crucial for early detection.
column4: Monitor and manage conditions that can contribute to increased intracranial pressure, such as head injuries or tumors.
column5: Strictly adhere to any prescribed medications to control intracranial pressure.
column6: Maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet and regular exercise, to support overall well-being.
column7: Seek immediate medical attention if experiencing symptoms like headaches, visual disturbances, or changes in consciousness.
